Piranha 3D was one of my favourite movies of 2010. It was not a remake of Joe Dante's classic 1978 but rather a reboot and second sequel. And now there's the next instalment, Piranha 3DD. Christopher Lloyd and Ving Rhames return for a another blood soaked, tittiefest. Using their network of underwater caves and rivers the piranha have migrated to another town where they find their way into a heavily populated waterpark... a SEXY waterpark. This might not have the same impact of the previous movie but its a very worthy sequel. It's got every cliche in the book, loads of big bouncing boobs, flesh chomping fishies and yes, another dick gag! Its super fun and exactly what you would hope to see, well me anyway. Add to the cast a cameo by Gary Busy, a self referential David HasselHoff (who has a great Baywatch moment) and David Koechner as the dickhead park owner. I was half expecting Piranha 3DD to be a cheap direct-to-dvd stinker but it maintains most of the quality of the last one... it was directed by the guy who made the 'Feast' trilogy, which was cool... oh and it has a wicked final frame, CHOMP!

I really liked the first Piranha 3D.  It was a great homage to B-movie creature features.  Lots of gore and stupid characters getting eating in gruesome ways.  It had tons of really great deaths and even some characters you actually kinda liked.  So when the sequel came out (geniously name Piranha 3DD!), I had to see it.  Unfortunately, I didn't get the chance to see it in 3D in the theater, but I finally found it ona Redbox and snatched it up.  And I must say... It is quite a disappointment.  3DD is less of a homage and more of a parody.  Which is fine, but it veers into Scary Movie territory and turns into nothing but a bunch of cheap pop culture references and unfunny gags.  The biggest offense is that the gore is ridiculously toned down.  It's obvious that this movie had a tiny budget and it really feels like a direct-to-video B-movie.  It has a few decent deaths, but most of the gore is hidden behind cloudy red water and anything substantial is replaced by people just running with red water all over them.  The huge Piranha invasion doesn't even happen until the last 20 minutes or so of the movie and the rest of it is wasted doing pretty much nothing.  It spends way more time showing naked girls then what you really want to see, which is people getting eaten by fish.  It's odd that the movie is hampered by budget and unable to do with better makeup effects because it's directed by John Gulager, who made the indie horror movie Feast, which was pretty good and had some good gore in it as well.  It could have been because this one was shot in 3D... I would have much preferred this be made in 2D and post-converted and had way better gore.

Another weird thing is that either the makeup department sucked in this movie, or the actors are purposely made up to look washed up and old.  Danielle Panabaker and Katrina Bowden, who are usually both very attractive and young-looking, both look old and washed up here.  What happened?

Anyway, the only thing this movie has going for it is that it's a direct sequel to the Iraq movie with some call-backs to it and even some recurring characters.  I'm not sure why they ditched to giant piranha thing the last movie ended with, though.  This movie again ends with a cliff hanger with the piranhas evolving, but eh, I didn't really care.

Just when you thought it was safe to go back in the water park... The piranhas are back in another outrageous outing with even more blood and boobs than ever before! Those pesky pre-historic piranhas have found their way into a new lake, but unfortunately for the locals, the lake also serves as the source for the the new Big Wet water park! If you thought PIRANHA 3D was in poor taste, you ain't seen nuthin' yet! The creative team behind the cult-classic FEAST takes over in this direct-to-video sequel, and they have really nailed it this time. PIRANHA 3DD shoots way over the top with its crude humor and exploitative fun, throwing political-correctness to the wind along with plenty of limbs and bikini tops. Don't let the 'R' rating fool you... This film has more gratuitous nudity and violence than any Uncut DVD on the market. All contextualized, of course. Where PIRANHA 3D never struck an even balance between the humor and horror, director John Gulager and writers Patrick Melton and Marcus Dunstan keep the pace moving a mile a minute as they shock, entertain, and completely disgust along the way. If that weren't enough, PIRANHA 3DD unleashes the one-and-only David Hasselhoff in a brilliant self-parody for the final act. Any fans who may have been disappointed with the last PIRANHA can get ready for a stupid good time with PIRANHA 3DD!

The film-makers don't' overstep the mark as it looks like enough thought was put into this sequel. Still shows innovative ways for piranhas to terrorise victims. This is one of the drawbacks as it doesn't have the great Florida Spring Break setting working for it like the original so every aspect of the story is on a smaller scale. The nudity seems slightly unnecessary this time round, not that male viewers will do much complaining. Takes a light-hearted approach to horror, a direction that really works in its favour in the final scenes at the water park where some of the silly jokes conjure up a few laughs. Commits the sin like practically all the 3D messes out there and inserts little 3D bits that appear tacky. Luckily, it doesn't bombard you with them. Can be enjoyed with some buddies when something easy is required but it is nothing to scream about.

Piranha 3DD is a fun movie, eclipsed by how stupid it is. This movie has very few redeeming qualities, but I'll try to name at least two. Some of the acting was acceptable for the type of movie it was, including David Hasselhoff, Christopher Lloyd, Gary Busey, and Danielle Panabaker, who played the protagonist pretty well. Also, the film has some jokes that hit the right spot, as well as certain scares or high tension moments that do leave you on the edge of your seat. However, a crummy story, bad character development, terrible effects, and a horror of a directing job all make this film a mediocre horror/comedy, which should've gone straight to DVD. Where this movie excels is in the pre-advertised nudity that the film presents from the very title. Topless women and random moments of humor based on sexual themes are put in the place of an actual compelling script, which keeps male audiences watching, but not truly interested in characters or where the story could go. Overall, I'd say it's a fun movie to watch with friends, if you've had a few drinks and/or don't mind watching a movie for the laughs of how bad and outrageous it is.

Piranha 3DD doubles up the ante, breast, gore, and cameos, but is a half*** film. Piranha 3DD continues after the bloody massacre in Lake Victoria. Swimmers and sun bathers retreat to the waterparks for safety, but that will no longer be any help since the piranhas have found a way to infiltrate it. Piranha 3DD includes a number of cameos from the previous films: Paul Scheer, Ving Rhames, and Christopher Lloyd. However, new guys step in like Gary Busey, David Koechner, and David Hasselhoff. Marine biologist student Maddy (Danielle Panabaker) returns to her old job at a water park for the summer. Among her friends, she is pleased until she discovers that her favorite water park has been turned into some sleazy sex pool for adults featuring topless babes and cameras by the ladders to capture shots of the female body, classy. All of this is from her stepdad Chet (Koechner) as he remodeled the place for his own appetite. Lifeguards are replaced with certified water strippers, swimming area for adults, and did I tell you the location of the camera? This sleazy perverted recreation is the least of Maddy's worries as friends begin to disappear at a nearby lake. Where could have they gone to? Well, it is discovered that piranhas are the culprit, so she goes to her friends who are also competing for her love: Barry (Matt Bush) and Kyle (Chris Zylka). They too are puzzled, so they go to the one man that will know the answers, Mr. Goodman (Lloyd). He warns them that piranhas are powerful to bite through steel and be attracted to chlorine for an utterly confusing reason. She pleads with Chet, but he is the least interest since tomorrow is the opening day, wow. Like said, the piranhas manage to infiltrate the water park and turn Big Wet into a Hometown Buffet. Piranha 3DD is the sequel to Piranha 3D which served as a revision rather than a remake. The film was fantastic and fun, but here Piranha 3DD is similar and a closer remake to the original film by Joe Dante. I still do not understand how the film is a parody of Jaws, but whatever. It is entertaining, wet, and wild, but also falls really short to being a completed film. I was quite disappointed with the writing and story. The acting is unintentionally funny with other laugh out loud, but feel bad moments. I wanted a little more closer with the characters and timing with girls in their bikinis. I also wanted to have a little more fun watching the Big Wet before the massacre because the film is only two parts: prior Big Wet's opening and the massacre. The piranhas were brought in a little too early.

A favorite comedian of mine and my girlfriend's to show up in an Arizona bayou, only to be devoured by these bottom-rate revamped piranhas (I wouldn't even call them third rate the design is THAT bad! ) is a complete waste of his talent! The "lifeguards" being sluts due to the oh-so-over-used "perverted old man" gig and one male lifeguard (David Hasselhoff) who doesn't even care about anything but publicity and beautiful women, it's just completely sickening! I would have to say that the only good things about this film are very few and INCREDIBLY far between. A horror-comedy? HAH! What a joke... Sorry to spoil it for any readers out there, but COME ON! A perverted old man reopens a water park, replaces all the GOOD lifeguards with "water certified" sluts and David Hasselhoff, the step-daughter hates him, and, what do you know, he's illegally pumping water into the park from a piranha infested lake. The two timing "cop" who's to chicken to even do anything, even to save the girl he's in love with, was just in it for the money, and the entire "plot" DARE I call it that, was completely skewered to these cheap-as-fuck, ass-wiping over-gore! 

I am just so appalled that they would dare call this a sequal, and to think, they left it open for a TRILOGY! WHAT THE HELL IS FUCKING WRONG WITH YOU?! Okay, I admit, I'm GLAD that they brought back the old marine biologist, Mr. Goodman, back, though they made him a little crazy and it was just terrible that they reused scenes from the first movie! We've already done the "get the slut from under the round floatie" thing. Why ruin something that was even better in the original? "Fish That Walk Among Us" hm... I do believe they, oh, I don't know... ALREADY EXIST ON THIS PLANET CURRENTLY! There ARE fish that can breathe air and "walk" on land for periods of time people! You don't need to make these cheap ass, failed remakes do it too! Another GOOD thing they did in this movie was bring back the sheriff, Ving Rhames "Deputy Fallon", from the first movie who kicked ass in the original at the cost of his legs. BUT they made him a total pussy, who's afraid of the water until the piranhas return, where he gets his original vamp back and saves some innocents, despite the fear. There was nothing really "funny" or "comedic" about the movie at all. The ONLY reason I laughed was because of what happened to Ashley, because, I'm "so mature." Come on, a piranha swam up into her, proceeded to tear her up from the inside out, then bit her fuck buddies dick! that's really all there was to that. 

Why? Why did you have to go and ruin something that, personally, was good and try to ruin it for me? Seriously... What a total disaster. Whatever you do, DON'T WATCH THIS F - - MOVIE!!!  You have better uses for your money and time.

The only good things about this movie: the cheesy-as-fuck love scenario where the guy does something he's afraid of most to save the girl (well, doesn't that sound like EVERY movie out there now-a-days?), Mr. Goodman, Deputy Fallon and his kickass-ness, the cameo of Gary Busey and the fact that the fat guy fucking blew up the water park with ammonia and chlorine, two extremely flammable chemicals, that's really it. The rest was just a waste of a movie and funding.

It is not worth any time to consider this movie at all for any kind of "good time." You'd be better off watching some other horror-comedy if you want to get your sick kicks. Or better yet, just watch some horror and comedy separately. Go watch Mirrors or The Exorcist or SOMETHING! This is not worthy of anyone's time.

This movie has no idea what it wants to be. Sometimes it's self aware of the fact that's it's stupid, silly, and over the top, and yet other times it tries to convey real heartfelt emotion that just comes across as annoying and unbelievable. Director John Gulager had no idea what he was doing when he made this. There is absolutely no direction in this film whatsoever. And the camera shots are all over the place and sometimes nauseating. It's almost like he tied a flip camera to a dog and let it run around a water park for an hour and whatever turned up he used. There are a couple shots in the film where for some reason the resolution of the camera just turned to shit. Like the scene where the cop car is driving down the road and the camera zooms out and the screen gets all fuzzy and blurry. Maybe i got a defective dvd or something, but I doubt it. The CGI is also horribly fake and honestly it kind of irritated me. You might think the only saving grace in this film would be the boobs, but guess what? Most of those aren't even fun to look at. They're mostly just gross saggy stripper boobs. This is probably the worst movie of 2012. Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance, John Carter, The Apparition, and House at the End of the Street are all contending but I think this one might barely squeeze out the victory. Save yourself the time and money and pass on this one.

Lame acting, poor effects and an even more anemic and outlandish premise (now at a water park instead of actually being on open water) than its predecessor immediately lands Piranha 3DD in hot water from the outset. The two Davids in the film (Koechner and Hasselhoff, the latter in a cameo) alongside Ving Rhames may make this not so awful, and while it's not completely bereft of any self-referential humour, the carnage and mayhem are just not as memorable as Alexandre Aja's original remake.

An extra D is accurate for Piranha 3DD. Yes, there are a lot more boobs than in this one. That also includes the clueless characters in this story. D is also an accurate grade for this film. What worked so well in Piranha 3D needs to be justified in 3DD, and it just doesn't work as well. The jokes aren't really that funny, and the cameo effectiveness is usually for just one sight gag and not well thought out (with a couple exceptions). Loosely held together by a boring story with meh characters, Piranha DD deflates as much as its A cup lead Maddy (Danielle Panabaker).

Across from Lake Victoria (the site of the first Piranha) the pack fish have found another entry to an adult water park run by Maddy's dad Chet (David Koechner). Maddy is home from summer vacation hanging out with her pot smoking (Paul James Jordan), slutty (Meagan Tandy), virginal (Katrina Bowden), virginity-taking (Jean-Luc Bilodeau), past-lover (Chris Zylka), and new love prospect (Matt Bush) friends. She is trying to save her family's waterpark and warn people about the fish, which shockingly fall on deaf ears. Deaths ensue, usually gory, some sexual, and the credits roll.

Anytime the plot brings up something that could be interesting, it reverts back to its trajectory. The chewed penis is brought back in the most elaborate inconcieveable way possible. The love triangle between Maddy, the ex, and the prospect actually had both guys be alright at the beginning, but they set the ex up to be secretly a bad guy by the middle because you're supposed to root for him (even though he can't swim). By minute 10 I was counting down to the bloody end, and it would be fine if the end was really pulpy fun. Instead it tries to set up too elaborate sight gags with little payoff. Several characters meet their end, and Koechner's is the only one kind of funny and shocking.

Piranha 3D had two of the best cameos in recent memory with Richard Dreyfus at the beginning and Jerry O'Connell as a Girls Gone Wild type. Offed in the first movie, they are replaced with Gary Busey (not great) and David Hasselhoff, the one bright spot, playing a bored version of himself who condescends to how stupid his own fans are. He gets most of the best lines, and was the only character I was rooting to not die. Christopher Lloyd reprises his character in the first with better lines and more fun. Paul Scheer and Ving Rhames are cute, but do not get enough screen time.

To spend more time talking about Piranha 3DD would mean that people would think I am recommending it. To earn your DD, just watch the first Piranha twice. The only saving grace of Piranha 3DD is that Piranha 3DDD needs to build their story around David Hasselhoff's movie script he was writing throughout the movie. That will be amazing.

Wow, I was not expecting the follow-up to the so-bad-it's-excellent Piranha 3D to pretty much just inhabit the "so bad" spectrum, though I ignored warning signs at my own risk. I found the 2010 Piranha to be a sheer blast of campy entertainment, with some world-class gore effects and a game cast. I was actually terribly excited about a sequel; I'm ashamed to admit it now. Where did things go so horribly wrong? Much like Expendables 2, the movie's tone shifts from tongue-in-cheek 80s throwback to meta self-awareness. The movie becomes more of a lousy comedy with some absurd violence rather than a horror movie with a nasty sense of humor. The entire premise is so labored, that a water park would become piranha-infested, and the characters are so unlikable; to dub them one-dimensional is to be too kind. The acting is abysmal even by bottom-of-the-barrel B-movie standards. The celebrity cameos feel wasted, with David Hasselhoff soaking up every second of desperation. The tension is next to nil and the gore effects are pretty cheesy, trading gallons of blood for ingenuity (many character deaths occur off screen, like Gary Busey's). Then once the piranhas strike, the movie just completely abandons any sense of reality and becomes a gonzo comedy of the absurd, with characters behaving like idiots from another dimension. There's even one character that gets decapitated by a simple string of flags. It's at this point that Piranha 3DD drops any slapped-together sense of purpose. And yet this ghoulish mess can only barely make it to a scant 70 minutes (good luck getting through the abominably unfunny end credits outtakes). Reportedly, 3DD had almost the same budget of 3D. Where the hell did that money go? Piranha 3DD completely misfires on every level, failing as a horror movie, a horror-comedy, a comedy, a gore movie, hell, as a suitable movie. Whatever the metric, this movie blows. If you're hard-pressed for gratuitous nudity soaked in blood, watch the superior 2010 Piranha film instead. I'm going to start drinking heavily and forget I ever looked forward to this monstrosity on taste.

It's pretty easy to see what happened when this film was in development:
1. The first movie was surprisingly successful, let's bring out the sequel!
2. We must use the DD gimmick.
3. Where would be an awesome place for all this Piranha shit to go down? A waterpark!
4. How can we make it even more awesome? Draft in some genre-favourites to the cast.

If Piranha 3DD had a third act or even an ending, then it would be almost just as entertaining as the first. It's got that self-parody, tongue-in-cheek, over-the-top ridiculousness that is of course welcomingly expected, plus ... yeah ... Gary Busey biting the head off of a baby piranha (even if it is only for a mere few minutes) and David Hassellhoff self-parodying himself (as he says, this is pretty much the lowest of the low). Sex, tits, blood, entertainment and laughs, but basically the whole thing is just one massive set-piece. There's a beginning (the lead-up to this adult waterpark's opening) and there's a middle (the piranhas entering the chaos) but there's no end. The writers have shoved in all the bullet point notes of what could be brilliant here and they've not worked to develop an ending. That mishap's a shame, but it's still just over an hour of bloody good fun and violence (hell, it felt like half hour to me!)! If you enjoyed the first film (which is much more memorable and - dare I say - "clever"), then seek this chaotic set-piece sequence out, even if you do have to wait for the price to drop significantly before the purchase.

(1 Star) Piranha DD... ugh. It's a failure as a sequel, as horror, as comedy, and as a movie. The first Piranha was so funny but this one is just sad. Christopher Lloyd is the only good part of this movie and he's only in a couple scenes. The gore is nowhere as awesome, the jokes are putrid (and they repeat them; there's only so many times that slow motion is funny), the characters are stock and stupid as hell, and it's barely a movie as the last ten minutes are terrible outtakes and extremely long end credits. Even though the first was extremely campy, it had a great cast that included Elisabeth Shue, Richard Dreyfus, and Eli Roth... this one has Gary Busey and about a million horrible David Hasselhoff jokes. Who honestly thinks Davide Hasselhoff is cool? They tried to doing for him what they did for Mike Tyson in The Hangover, but it's eye-rolling and an embarrassing waste of time.

The first was smutty, but it was a great self-parody. DD removed all of the funny and upped the smut to unenjoyable levels. There's three editors for this turkey and it shows... there are a lot of scenes that feel rushed. I can't remember any of the teen character names; they're all the same stupid dead teenager character you've seen in a million slasher flicks. Piranha DD is stupid, but not the amusing kind of stupid... it's infuriating. Making a sequel to a fun campy movie shouldn't be this awful. I was not expecting a good movie; I was expecting a funny imitation and they failed.

Back in 2010, a sleeper hit called Piranha 3D hit theaters and treated viewers to a teenage wonderland of carnage and gratuitous nudity.Personally, the first film was not perfect, but it knew what it was and had fun with it making the movie fun to watch.  Needless to say it appealed to enough people to inspire the sequel Piranha 3DD a significantly horrendous film that takes everything remotely enjoyable from the first movie and makes it vile and not fun in the least bit. I can not express enough how much i personally loathe the film. There is nothing remotely entertaining about this film and there was a few things going for it but it was all held back by logic, script, plot, and how much it relies on cameos and nudity. The overall point of being a sequel is to somehow continue the story in a linear fashion. They mention the first movie at the very beginning and about three quarters of the way in, but the logic for the sequel doesnt make any sense. They say that this piranha attack would be worse than the one in the first film, but the attack takes place in a decently populated water park and the first was at a lake during Spring Break. In what world does a water park out weigh a massacre at a lake during Spring Break? It just doesn't make sense. The they revealed theat there were giant piranhas in the last film, but they are nowhere to be found in this one but somehow they evolve. The story is just sloppy to say the least. The story revolves around a piranha attack in a water park, but theres a bad love triangle and typical horror movie cliches that dumb this movie down below the point of cheesey horror. Plus the addition of terrible cgi blod and piranhas just make the story even more of a hard sell. On top of the worst logic imaginalbe, the script is not helping this abomination. The dialogue is so bad, i found it hard to even laugh at how bad it is. The dialogue revolves around profanity when the jokes arn't landing and then they try and throw in as many  jokes as possible to try and pander to the college audience. It doesn't work at all because the movie is that bad. The main problem i had with this movie is how much it relied on cameos and nudity. There are great choices for cameos mainly with Gary Busey and David Hasselhoff. Great choices because they are univerally funny, until they made this garbage. They don't work, Busey is too serious and Hassellhoff comes off as a jerk rather than a funny cameo. The main cameo that bothered me  was Ving Rhames. They made his chracter a legless veteran that wears his same clothes he did in the last movie and is now scared of water. It's not funny, its sad and poor writing. The movie's main sell is on the amount of nudity that is in it. In their defense, they didn't lie. There is a large amount of female nudity, but it was to the point where they relied on it to make people like the movie, but the camera work is so shoddy the nudity even looks bad. Let me rephrase, granted these girls make a barbie doll look like a real person, but still, it takes extra effort to make nudity bad in a teenage college movie. Overall, i can not express my hatred for this pile of filth enough. It isn't funny, it isn't entertaining, the gore looks bad, this is just a terrible excuse of a movie and will porbably top my list for the worst movies of 2012. I hate this movie and can not express how much i reccomend you don't watch this movie.

As trashy as its name suggests, Piranha 3DD (or Piranha DD as its 2D version has been dubbed for DVD) follows in the footsteps of its predecessor by blending comedy, nudity, and gore together into a thoroughly exploitative and yet completely entertaining piece of trash cinema.  Set in a water park that features an adult pool and other naughty amenities, Piranha 3DD is perhaps not as clever in its satire as the first film, but it still manages to be a funny and twisted piece of B-level cinema for those who are not easily offended and who have a warped sense of humor.

Sequel to last year's Piranha 3D (Which in itself is a remake) is nowhere near as fun but, it is also not as bad as it's been made out to be. Problem is, director John Gulager seems to take the material a little too seriously despite a script that replaces Piranha 3D's wit for blatantly stupid. And stupid would be fine in the case of a story about prehistoric piranha who travel from the decimated Lake Victoria through an underground river to a sleazy water theme park, if, director Gulager took the ball and ran with it like Alexandre Aja did. His cast is fine but, again only David Hasselhoff is in on the joke and the rest of the cast, including pretty lead Danielle Panabaker, are just too straight faced for a goofy flick like this. I do understand that the budget was smaller and thus the film's scale and carnage lesser but, look how fun the low budget original was without the budget and carnage of the 2011 remake. Joe Dante knew to play it serious to a point but, all the while letting the cast and audience in on the fun. When you open a film with Gary Busey and a dead cow that farts piranha eggs, there's no point in pretending you're directing Jaws. The gore effects are fine although the CGI is even weaker then it's predecessor but, despite it's faults, there is some entertainment to be had. The cameos from some of the survivors from the last entry are fun and there are some funny bits, most involving The Hoff. It could have been a lot better but, Piranha 3DD did pass the time and I actually feel that with a better script and more serious story, John Gulager might actually deliver a decent B-movie. An OK time waster but, far short of the deliriously fun remake that precedes it.

Just when you thought it was safe to go to your local water park, "Piranha 3DD" is released on not-so-innocent viewers. The follow-up to 2010's critically acclaimed box-office success "Piranha" did little business in theaters. Hopefully it will gain a little more attention from home audiences.

A school of mutated piranhas enter a water park through its piping systems. The step-daughter of its crooked co-owner must find a way to close off the man-eating creatures' access to the amusement facility. The employees of the park attempt to rescue the thrill-seeking swimmers before they're devoured by the aquatic monsters.

Roger Corman's name may not be found in the credits of this sequel, but his spirit is felt throughout it. It's the usual over-the-top creature feature we've all become accustomed to seeing from the B-movie king. Imagine "Jaws" if it took place in a water park the kids in "Porky's" worked at during the summer. That's the level of entertainment you get from watching "Piranha 3DD."

The CGI and practical effects are a grade above what one would expect from a movie of this nature. There are parts where the piranhas look less than spectacular, but it doesn't distract from the overall fun atmosphere of the film. Most of the special make-up effects are very well-done. The different severed body parts all look impressively realistic.

"Piranha 3DD" delivers B-movie schlock in its finest form. I don't know how it could get any better (or worse?) than this. It's crude, gory, funny, and successfully self-aware. A great high-definition transfer and a few interesting special features make this a recommended buy for fans of Roger Corman creature features and the likes.

So I thought that I needed to start reviewing movies properly again... So what better way than with the one and only Piranha 3DD. Now this movie has been completely and utterly ripped apart by critics and audiences a like, and I can see why, but after all these reviews, my standards were so low that it did surprise me on the main factor that I didn't think this movie was boring and I actually thought that Hasselhoff was the best part of this movie and actually created a few funny, and even clever moments. Now saying that he is 'the best part of the movie' isn't the biggest of compliments, I can appreciate that, but this movie isn't as god awful as some have said, and I think it is justifiable sequel to the first movie, although there is a lot of bad in this movie don't get me wrong. With pretty awful directing and some of the worst lines in recent movie history, it was bad on that scale, but, for me, it surpassed the scale of just being bad, but enjoyably bad. I enjoyed it enough that I don't hate it and that is down to a few parts here and there that just made it better, e.g. Christopher Lloyd, The Hoff and Gary Busey, apart from that that the performances are pretty god awful, but it is only 70 minutes long with actual story, so it isn't exactly slow, but I expected so much worse and just settled for a less than average. The only reason this isn't lower is because of the funny cameos, although it was depressing to see them in a sequel to Piranha out of anything else, but this will have to do for now.

The direction in this movie is pretty messy, with a lot of choppy editing and some shots that generally just look bad. It did seem to lack some of the real funny moments from the first one and I would have to say, similar to the first, that the first 30 minutes or so are just god awful, with some scenes that are so ridiculously gory and stupid that it just puts you off the movie, and then lines that followed that were made for laughs but just came off as lazy and stupid. That is the main problem with the direction here is that everything just felt a bit lazy, especially in the first half of this movie, as people ponder around, a few set pieces, but there are so many scenes with awful acting from the nobody actors and actresses of the horror industry, that you just watch and start to roll your eyes, line by line. The main problem here is that the ending is set up throughout the movie and you are waiting and waiting, then it happens, and then you are waiting and waiting and waiting. Credits. And that is it, you just experienced something that is respectfully risky but equally grotesque and slightly over the line. But still there is so much more fun that could have been had here, as they bring these interesting side characters in, who are so much more interesting and fun compared to the main characters, and they don't get much to do, and it reflected so poorly on the film.

This is the problem that I almost feel bad for giving this film a higher rating as I am truly aware that this is a bad, bad movie in a lot of ways, but I strangely enjoyed it at the same time, although being aware that everything that was happening was bad. The script in this movie was pretty awful and I think some of the lines just fell through, and I remember one line that David Koechner to his step daughter that is so childish and obviously lazy that is really off putting to watch on screen. Added to this, there are a few things that happen that just feel unnecessary, as some people who were bad first then find resolutions who are then killed off etc, and with a mildly amusing ending which brings it back to the feeling of the first film, where it gets that exploitation feel. It then ends. And it just feels a bit empty, and you then realize that this movie was extremely short, and should have probably just been a straight to DVD, or Straight to 3D Blu-ray. Also, I will say that I thought the 3D was fine and there were a few moments that worked well, but there seemed to be a few scenes that were a bit messy, and other scenes that seemed to be lacking in that real 3D effect.

The movie as a whole is simply down to how much you are bothered by the complete stupidity of the film, and how much you enjoy turning your brain off. I agree that you shouldn't have to. and especially to this extent, but if you have that ability, whenever Hasselhoff or Lloyd is on screen you will probably have a reasonably good time, but then the main characters will start speaking. And then it will just end.

Piranha 3DD is the sequel to the to the 2010 remake, which happens to be one of my favorites in my 3D movie collection.  I was excited to see the red band trailer with the realization that Project Greenlight horror director, John Gulagar was taking the helm.  The film's marketing promises more bustier bikini-wearing girls losing their tops to escape the flesh eating fish, and it lives up to it's promise.  However, don't go into the sequel with high expectations because neither the story, the CGI of the Piranha, nor the quality of fleshy women even come close to its predecessor.  

Maddy, Danielle Panabaker, is a college coed with a wicked stepfather who perverting her mother's water park, turning it into an adult themed fun land.  Meanwhile, the prehistoric piranhas have found a way out of Lake Victoria into the stripper-filled cesspool, and it's Maddy who leads the charge to save the water park guests.  It is not a bad premise, but there is a lack of development and introduction to the characters in the story.  Matt Bush is perfect to play the nerdy kid infatuated with Maddy, but he's given no satisfying character arc.  Although he needs to be pathetic, a redeeming quality should be revealed to convince the audience and Maddy to fall in love with him.   

There are some good casting choices in the film.  Christopher Lloyd returns as the scientist who studies the fish; he was a wonderful surprise in the first film.  David Koechner is perfect for the role as a sleazy stepfather.  And David Hasselhoff was actually hilarious reprising his role as a Baywatch lifeguard.  However, a travesty was committed when casting the most important roles.  There may have been double the D's, but they cast girls of the hard plastic variety.  I find it appalling that the director didn't spend more time casting these most vital roles to the movie.   

On a more serious note, Piranha 3DD is missing a scenes that portray an interesting evolution of the fish or a scientific discovery from studying other predator fish.  It would have been exciting to see a school of piranha come up against another predator like a shark or an alligator.  I could imagine a shark swallowing a Piranha, only to be eaten from the inside out by the nasty fish.  Another example is the fish that can sense urine in the water and swims up a man's penis.  This would add a reason not to pee in the pool.   All this would add to the terror of swimming with a school of these fish in a pool.  

In the end, the film is an obvious melodrama about the dangers of promiscuous sex although the producers blatantly use tantalizing tits and astronomic asses to sell a ticket or dvd rental to thirteen year olds who still haven't figured out internet porn.  Piranha 3DD needed more story elements that furthered the mythology and evolution of the piranha, characters the audience care about, and more authentic bouncy buoyant boobs.  That being said, I still secretly hope there's a Piranha III 3D.

I am the only person I know who has seen all four Piranha movies, so you can take it from me: this doesn't even constitute as being watchable.  This is even worse than Piranha II: The Spawning, and that was kind of a mess.  Originally, this series was all about being a Jaws spoof, but now it's all about crowbarring in as many terrible special effects and bad sex jokes as possible.  Everything about this is harebrained, from the terrible decisions every character makes throughout to just green lighting this atrocious script; it's more than obvious they didn't have any ideas for this, so why even make it?  Apart from David Koechner, who will be in anything for a paycheck, all of the stars look alarmingly distraught to be here: from a Gary Busey cameo to the Ving Rhames reprisal (didn't he die in the last movie?), and from Christopher Lloyd's five minutes to David Hasselhoff completely selling his soul for about two dozen Baywatch jokes, it is all just a sad sight to behold.  The dialogue is just awful, and the acting is even worse, and on top of that, there is also the fact that this is really poorly shot.  Most direct-to-video movies are better than this, and it is just offensively bad.

Some unknown years after the last Piranha attack, the evil fish return and this time look to hit up a water park and make a splash.  I was surprised at how much I enjoyed Piranha 3-D so I was a little letdown by this sequel.  The fact that the film makes fun of itself knowing it's bad is what made the first film so enjoyable.  3DD has that but it's just not as good a second time around.  The plot is paper-thin but really, it doesn't have to be Inception here.  The script itself is full of cheesy dialogue although there are some quotes here that I will never forget, especially one from Katrina Bowden.  Like the first film, it's more of a comedy than it a horror flick, but there are some very gory and bloody scenes.  Some of the moments here will have you rolling your eyes but there are some kills here that are flat out hilarious.  There's also a lot of nudity, unfortunately not from any of the main characters I wanted to see. The cast includes Danielle Panabaker as Maddy, our heroaine, Matt Bush as Barry, the guy who likes Maddy, David Koechner as Chet, the sleazy owner of the water park, Katrina Bowden as Shelby, a dumb blonde virgin, Chris Zylka as Kyle, Ving Rhames reprises his role as Deputy Fallon and Christopher Lloyd is back as well as the wacky Piranha expert.  One of the highlights of the film is a fun cameo from David Hasselhoff.  Make it clear, Piranha 3DD is in no way a great film but it did it's job of entertaining me and it was still better than Battleship.

Well the story of the film is pretty much Jaws 3-D, just with Piranhas. The Piranhas from the first film find a way to get in a water park and wreak havoc. 
 
Piranha 3DD doesn't really hold much in terms of deep storytelling, special effects etc. But viewers who just want to have fun while having spare time and money could enjoy it.  The film contains comedy, nudity and lots of gore. And gore hounds may cheer with joy when they see this. But I don't think the amount of gore rivals that of its predecessor. 

The film benefits from some recognizable faces such as David Hasselhoff who played Mitch Buchannon in Baywatch and Christopher Lloyd who played Dr. Emmett Brown in the Back to the Future films.  David Hasselhoff plays a parody of himself in this film, expressing a more killjoy persona while Christopher Lloyd reprises his role as Mr. Goodman. Seeing both these characters in film gives a viewer like me a sense of nostalgia which added to the overall enjoyment of the film. And the two give funny and enjoyable performances, David Hasselhoff in particular. Danielle Panabaker plays the main heroine for the film. Panabaker is a pretty seasoned actress, appearing in films such as Sky High, The Crazies, The Ward, as well as a bunch of TV shows such as the Guardian, Law and Order Special Victims Unit etc. Panabaker does an okay job of portraying her character, though her character here doesn't leave that much of an impression in my eyes. The film also benefits from some scenes with Ving Rhames and Garey Busey.  

The movie is probably not much to behold. But I think the movie does a good job of having the viewers forget their troubles for a few minutes, and I think that's what it's supposed to do.

Alexandre Aja's Piranha 3D was hardly a masterpiece, but it was a real movie. It was well shot, featured some pretty great makeup effects and sported a decent amount of tension, balanced with zany comedy. The film took the charactersAlexandre Aja's Piranha 3D was hardly a masterpiece, but it was a real movie. It was well shot, featured some pretty great makeup effects and sported a decent amount of tension, balanced with zany comedy. The film took the characters seriously, even though the horror spewing mayhem of the killer fish all around them was laugh-inducing. That was part of the film's charm. John Gulager's follow-up, on the other hand, has no charm, or class for that matter. Piranha 3DD is an awful film because it doesn't understand what made the first film work for most audiences. Instead, it swaps sly political and social subtext for stale, shameful cameos, derp jokes and juvenile gags fit for a crass Meet the Spartans-type spoof. Picking up a little while after the events of the first film, Piranha 3DD brings the killer fish to a wild water park run by a sleazy entrepreneur (David Koechner). And that's pretty much the whole plot of the film, which barely runs over an hour (sans credits). The water park is overrun with the monster fish, and the final twist of the first film (that there are mega piranhas) is pretty much left untapped. The characters are meaningless, and there's not a likeable soul inhabiting a single corner of picture. The film is gory, sure, but even the violence and mayhem isn't nearly as shocking, or amusing. It's just bloody and uninventive. The nudity also feels dialed back, which is bizarre given the film takes place at a water park patrolled by stripper lifeguards. There's breasts and bums all over the place, but Aja's film pulled a few full frontal scenes, including a hilariously tantalizing underwater ballet. There's nothing here that tops that, nor does the film ever even seem to want to try. And that's the problem with Piranha 3DD  it's not trying, at all. It's just a shallow, muddy killer fish film with paper-thin characters, an insultingly boring narrative and lifeless thrills. The cameos are remarkably embarrassing, especially a seemingly drunken David Hasselhoff (who's seen better days). The returning actors from the previous film (Ving Rhames, Christopher Lloyd and Paul Scheer  who died off-screen, mind you) stick out like a sore thumb, too. They don't work in the world Gulager has created, because his world isn't logical, and it's populated by moronic stereotypes and unrealistic non-human humans. Piranha 3DD is a terrible film, and that's a tragedy. There was room for a good sequel to Alexandre Aja's original, but John Gulager and crew messed it all up. What remains is pretty solid Blu-ray for a film that's barely even worth renting.

Given the extremely low user and critic reviews, I thought I, someone who loved Piranha 3D, would be greatly disappointed in this film.  But this film was hilarious!  What I don't understand is how people can criticize the movie for itsGiven the extremely low user and critic reviews, I thought I, someone who loved Piranha 3D, would be greatly disappointed in this film.  But this film was hilarious!  What I don't understand is how people can criticize the movie for its story, acting, etc.  The movie is about a bunch of prehistoric piranhas that get into a water park where girls run around naked.  The film revels in its own absurdity, and that's what is so great about it.  What did you expect, Rosemary's Baby?

As a 3D film, it's abysmal.  Piranha 3DD was not shot in 3D to begin with, but is another of those post conversion hack jobs.  It doesn't help matters that the little fishies are framed in tight close-ups--it's all foreground, when the formatAs a 3D film, it's abysmal.  Piranha 3DD was not shot in 3D to begin with, but is another of those post conversion hack jobs.  It doesn't help matters that the little fishies are framed in tight close-ups--it's all foreground, when the format needs deep backgrounds; no depth, no 3D.    The attacks are never scary, however, Piranha 3DD gets the job done when it goes for parody, especially of Jaws.  One of TV's most famous lifeguards makes an extended cameo, and a cast member of the original film gets a funny scene as well.  Full review on my blog.

Somehow even hornier than its predecessor. DD takes an almost no holds barred approach when it comes to trying to one-up 3D in vulgarity and nudity. On top of there being fake breasts as far as the eye can see, these are also some of the mostSomehow even hornier than its predecessor. DD takes an almost no holds barred approach when it comes to trying to one-up 3D in vulgarity and nudity. On top of there being fake breasts as far as the eye can see, these are also some of the most crass and crude gags I've ever witnessed. While some things like a farting cow corpse complete with a working butthole were a bit too juvenile for even my tastes, for the most part I was perfectly content to go along for the ride.That's because I don't demand too much from my B-movies, particularly not Piranha. Even back in 1978 all these films were really good for was a little bit of boobage, a lot of blood, and plenty of wacky hijinks along the way. So the lengths this is willing to go to in order to top the rest of the series in at least two of those categories was perfectly fine by me. That's what I came for after all.The only area where it takes a bit of a step back is in the carnage department. There's still plenty of gore and mayhem, but director John Gulager's kills are nowhere near as creative as Alexandre Aja's. Plus, trading the open lake setting of the previous entry for that of a water park makes the feeding frenzy feel much smaller in comparison. The entrail strewing goods are still delivered in a competent enough manner to make for a solid creature feature regardless, it's just clear they didn't really go for broke here like they did everywhere else.While I have yet to see Piranha II: The Spawning, I can't imagine it's any raunchier or more ridiculous than this. With tongue planted firmly in cheek, the franchise's most immature elements have been placed front and center and get taken to wild new heights. There's stuff here so nasty and irreverent you'd think you were watching another Seth Rogen/Evan Goldberg collaboration. It's definitely dumb and gratuitous, but as someone who is really only in attendance for the sleazier aspects anyways I had fun seeing things get taken to the next self-aware level. Honestly, in a way it's kind of glorious in its tastelessness and stupidity.6.9/10

The first film, "Piranha," was adored by many as a guilty pleasure or a shot in the arm of cheese.  Now we are given, "Piranha 3DD," which has the same pre-historic flesh eating army of piranhas moving from a vacation lake locale to aThe first film, "Piranha," was adored by many as a guilty pleasure or a shot in the arm of cheese.  Now we are given, "Piranha 3DD," which has the same pre-historic flesh eating army of piranhas moving from a vacation lake locale to a chlorine filled water-park.  Much is much the same, but just more gory, more nudity, and more senselessness.  This sequel has a new director in John Gulager ("Feast"), but it does not offer anything fresh.  Just more gross out deaths that come across as more head-shaking than elaborate of shocking.  The only returning cast members are Christopher Lloyd as Carl, whom is the nutty scientist character that learns more about the ancient piranhas, and Ving Rhames as Sheriff Fallon, whom we all thought died in the first, but only lost his legs to the piranhas and is now able to attach a shotgun as leg instead.  New to the cast is the young Danielle Panabaker ("Sky High" and "Friday the 13th") as the lead and David Koechner ("Anchorman") as her dim-witted stepfather and owner of the water park where the majority of the killing takes place.  If you are a fan of the original, you may enjoy this one, but it is just same gore fest over again shot entirely in 3D and of course with continuous nudity of young women.  The only mere bright spot is a the cameo of David Hasselhoff as himself.  He actually has a few really funny scenes poking fun at himself and his career, but it comes nowhere close to saving the film.  Gary Busey also makes a early cameo in the film, but its a mellow return to film for him, it might have worked better for him if he actually poked fun of himself like Hasselhoff rather than playing a character.  Bottom line:  Only notable thing about the film is a cameo by Hasselhoff, the rest is a forgettable, gore dunce fest that overstays its welcome.

Just when you thought it was safe to go back in the water park... The piranhas are back in another outrageous outing with even more blood and boobs than ever before! Those pesky pre-historic piranhas have found their way into a new lake, butJust when you thought it was safe to go back in the water park... The piranhas are back in another outrageous outing with even more blood and boobs than ever before! Those pesky pre-historic piranhas have found their way into a new lake, but unfortunately for the locals, the lake also serves as the source for the the new Big Wet water park! If you thought PIRANHA 3D was in poor taste, you ain't seen nuthin' yet! The creative team behind the cult-classic FEAST takes over in this direct-to-video sequel, and they have really nailed it this time. PIRANHA 3DD shoots way over the top with its crude humor and exploitative fun, throwing political-correctness to the wind along with plenty of limbs and bikini tops. Don't let the 'R' rating fool you... This film has more gratuitous nudity and violence than any Uncut DVD on the market. All contextualized, of course. Where PIRANHA 3D never struck an even balance between the humor and horror, director John Gulager and writers Patrick Melton and Marcus Dunstan keep the pace moving a mile a minute as they shock, entertain, and completely disgust along the way. If that weren't enough, PIRANHA 3DD unleashes the one-and-only David Hasselhoff in a brilliant self-parody for the final act. Any fans who may have been disappointed with the last PIRANHA can get ready for a stupid good time with PIRANHA 3DD!

The answer: 87 minutes of nudity, unneeded snap zooms, overly color corrected blue water, and absolutely zero plot or character development. I always try to find good in a film, but there are very few aspects of Piranha 3DD that made me enjoy it. The idea this film is based around is far-fetched to start with, but the creative team took it to an unfortunate extreme. Who was the protagonist? Who was the antagonist? What is stasis A and what is stasis B? Why do I care about any of the character's fates in this slaughterfest? If the director or any of the actors could answer these questions I would be impressed. It's a pandemonium of scenes spliced together and put on screen. This movie was made for the money not ratings, which is a shame. What is the Sci-fi/Horror genre becoming?

One of the worst films ever made - and not in a good wayThe first Piranha surprised audiences in 2010 with its wit, over the top nudity, and excessive gore. It never took itself seriously and had a solid cast. This follow-up to the 2010 movie is just honestly embarrassing. It had all the elements that the first movie had, but everything goes horribly wrong with incompetent direction, laughably bad acting and dialogue, and some of the cheapest gore effects I've ever seen.Why is this movie so bad? Let's start with the plot - there is none. If you can buy the premise that piranhas are going to go in underground lakes and somehow end up in a water park swimming, well then I have a bridge to sell you as well. The characters are all terrible. The one couple in the van early on exists only to die, no other purpose, no even attempted development. Yet later we see other characters mourning their disappearance, only it's forgotten 5 minutes later. The one scene that people will probably remember involves a girl that had a piranha swim up her lady parts (and somehow survive) only to bite her boyfriend's penis during intercourse. Trying to be inventive there, but really just shows the lack of any restraint with this movie. But even if you think the plot and acting are atrocious, at least there will be good gore, right? Wrong. The gore effects can be described in one word: cheap. The special effects with the piranhas are terrible too - you wonder where they spent $20 million on this movie. Not to mention, the inevitable massacre scene is shot so poorly that it has zero coherence and lacks any punch. It looks like they just poured some red dye in the pool and hired a few extras to flop around. The massacre scene in the first film had some of the best gore effects I'd ever seen. This is a joke of a follow-up.So which actors disgraced themselves for a paycheck? There is a cameo by David Hasselhoff where he's basically mocking himself, but you have to wonder what is going through his head when his character mutters "Welcome to rock bottom." I wonder if the irony is lost on this man. David Koechner is just obnoxious and terrible. Jerry O'Connell played this type of character way better in the first film. Every time Koechner was on screen, I was just wanting him to get killed off already.And also surprisingly, we don't even get any good nudity. All the extras they hired for this movie look like washed up strippers. None of the cute female leads goes topless. Maybe they ran out of budget and couldn't pay them enough to do it.I have a feeling that 95% of the people involved in this film will ever have meaningful work in Hollywood again (thankfully). Don't waste your time.

rt_summary: Though it was once a wholesome, family-oriented attraction, a water park owned by Chet (David Koechner) now features a nudist pool and aquatic strippers. Chet's daughter, a marine biologist named Maddy (Danielle Panabaker), is unhappy about the changes but is powerless to stop the grand reopening. However, when a school of ravenous, prehistoric piranha migrate over from nearby Lake Victoria, Maddy must somehow prevent the park's patrons from becoming fish food.
meta_summary: After the terror unleashed on Lake Victoria in Piranha 3DD, the pre-historic school of blood thirsty piranhas are back. This time, no one is safe from the flesh eating fish as they sink their razor sharp teeth into the visitors of summer’s best attraction, The Big Wet Water Park. (Dimension Films)
